turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Naturally, one does not take much stock in such a piece of filth but, on the other hand, it is not the sort of thing one can simply ignore. What do you think, Joseph?

turns.speaker: JOSEPH
turns.text: No...

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Junot?

turns.speaker: JOSEPH
turns.text: No... nothing at all.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Not even the slightest hint of something?

turns.speaker: JOSEPH
turns.text: No -- Captain Charles commanded the cavalry escort, and rode outside the carriage.  In the evenings, he always ate at another table.  They hardly ever spoke to each other.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: You would tell me, Joseph, wouldn't you?

turns.speaker: JOSEPH
turns.text: Yes, of course, I would.  You know I am not one of your wife's greatest admirers, but I certainly know nothing about this.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: And you, Junot?

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: The important thing is to find the right lawyer.  One who will not protract the thing indefinitely, in the courts.

turns.speaker: JOSEPH
turns.text: You know I am only too happy to be of help to you, but surely this isn't the ideal moment to involve yourself in such matters.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: I know of no better time.

turns.speaker: JOSEPH
turns.text: You can't be serious.  It would not be good to become another husband out of a Moliere farce.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: The comedy of my marriage is sufficiently well known already.

turns.speaker: JOSEPH
turns.text: You must not act impetuously.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: It is time to clarify the situation. Everything is over between us.

turns.speaker: JOSEPH
turns.text: But you can do the same thing in six months.  The next few weeks may be the most important ones in your life.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: My mind is made up.  She will not set foot in my house again.  I think if I saw her again, I might be tempted to strangle her.

turns.speaker: JOSEPH
turns.text: Are you sure that you are not still in love with her?

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Are you trying to insult me?

turns.speaker: JOSEPH
turns.text: Of course not, but such violence of feeling makes me wonder.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Well, you shall see.

turns.speaker: JOSEPH
turns.text: When is she supposed to return?

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: I have no idea.  Her maid said she left two days ago, to meet me -- I can imagine where she is.  But when she finally does come home, she will find her things in the street and my door locked.

turns.speaker: JOSEPH
turns.text: She will probably appear with a dozen excuses and you will forgive her anyway.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: My dear Joseph, the only thing that is clear is that my wife is a slut -- and while a man may want a slut for his mistress, he does not want her for his wife.

turns.speaker: JOSEPH
turns.text: Will you use the troops?

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Only as a last resort.  What are the Councils doing now?

turns.speaker: JOSEPHINE
turns.text: Ah, my dear Madame de Montesquiou, you have no idea what happiness it brings me to see this child, at last.  I was told the very idea of such a visit would too much distress the Empress.

turns.speaker: MONTESQUIOU
turns.text: I am delighted to be of service to you again, Your Highness.  And I can tell you, my instructions came directly from the Emperor, with a caution to be discreet.

turns.speaker: JOSEPHINE
turns.text: Oh... I see.  I understand.  How is... the Emperor?

turns.speaker: MONTESQUIOU
turns.text: I rarely see him, Your Highness, but I believe he is in excellent health, and he is very happy with the child.

turns.speaker: JOSEPHINE
turns.text: Ah, that is good.

turns.speaker: MONTESQUIOU
turns.text: And, you seem in excellent health, Your Highness.

turns.speaker: JOSEPHINE
turns.text: Ah, well, my dear Madame de Montesquiou, peace of mind can eventually be a substitute for happiness.

turns.speaker: JOSEPHINE
turns.text: Ah, how nice to meet you, General Bonaparte.  One has read so much about you lately.  Please sit down.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Thank you, Madame de Beauharnais. You probably don't recall but we met briefly a few months ago, at a party at Paul's house.

turns.speaker: JOSEPHINE
turns.text: Oh... yes, of course!  Have you met my daughter, Hortense?

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Yes, we introduced ourselves at the door.

turns.speaker: JOSEPHINE
turns.text: May I offer you a drink?

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Oh, I don't want to put you to any inconvenience.

turns.speaker: JOSEPHINE
turns.text: Oh, it's not the slightest inconvenience, General Bonaparte. It is an honor to have you here.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: You are very kind, Madame de Beauharnais.  Do you have some sherry, perhaps?

turns.speaker: JOSEPHINE
turns.text: Yes, of course.  Hortense, darling, will you tell Louise to bring some sherry?

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: I hope you will forgive me for barging in on you like this, Madame de Beauharnais.  I called to bring this to your son, but I understand from your charming daughter that he is out for the afternoon.

turns.speaker: JOSEPHINE
turns.text: Yes, I'm afraid he is.  I believe he is riding.  I know he'll be heartbroken to have missed you.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Well, I'm sure that you will be just as pleased to have this as he will be.

turns.speaker: JOSEPHINE
turns.text: Oh... how very nice of you to bring that for Eugene... Did General de Beauharnais give it to you?

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: No, I'm afraid I never had the pleasure of meeting the General. This sword was taken several days ago from your son by some of my soldiers.

turns.speaker: JOSEPHINE
turns.text: Oh, you must forgive me, General Bonaparte, I'm afraid you will think me incredibly stupid but I know absolutely nothing about this. Eugene is so independent -- he hardly tells me anything any more, and he has so many things in his room, I must confess I wasn't even aware that he had this sword -- you know how boys can be!

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Were you in love with him?

turns.speaker: JOSEPHINE
turns.text: I thought I was.  I was confused.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: And now?

turns.speaker: JOSEPHINE
turns.text: Now, I know that I shall die if you leave me.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Do you expect me to believe that?

turns.speaker: JOSEPHINE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: JOSEPHINE
turns.text: And you, are you in love with any one else?

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: JOSEPHINE
turns.text: But you have had mistresses while you were away.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Of course.

turns.speaker: JOSEPHINE
turns.text: Were you in love with any of them?

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: JOSEPHINE
turns.text: Were they pretty?

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: JOSEPHINE
turns.text: Were any of them prettier than I am?

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: One had better legs.

turns.speaker: JOSEPHINE
turns.text: Were any of them married?

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Yes.  They were the easiest.  I made love to one of them within ten minutes of our first meeting.

turns.speaker: JOSEPHINE
turns.text: She must have been in love with you.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Not in the least.  After all, what is adultery -- only a brief transaction on a couch, requiring a few minutes of privacy.

turns.speaker: JOSEPHINE
turns.text: Promise me you will never leave me.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: I cannot promise you that.

turns.speaker: JOSEPHINE
turns.text: Promise me.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: I will never forgive you.

turns.speaker: JOSEPHINE
turns.text: I don't care, but promise you will never leave me.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: I don't understand you.

turns.speaker: JOSEPHINE
turns.text: Promise.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Promises mean nothing.

turns.speaker: JOSEPHINE
turns.text: Perhaps -- but tell me you promise, anyway.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: All right -- I promise.

turns.speaker: JOSEPHINE
turns.text: You are my old friend.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Yes -- what is it?

turns.speaker: JOSEPHINE
turns.text: Open the door.  It's me.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Go away -- I'm busy.

turns.speaker: JOSEPHINE
turns.text: I know what you're doing in there.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Don't be ridiculous and go away -- I'm busy working.

turns.speaker: JOSEPHINE
turns.text: Where is Madame Trillaud?

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: How should I know.  Ask Roquier -- he's cleaning her dress.

turns.speaker: JOSEPHINE
turns.text: What are you doing in there?

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Oh -- now, this is absolutely ridiculous!  If you don't want to be humiliated in front of your guests, you will return to the table at once.

turns.speaker: JOSEPHINE
turns.text: Will you be joining us, soon?

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: I will be there in five minutes.  Go back to your guests.

turns.speaker: JOSEPHINE
turns.text: Five minutes.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Yes!!

turns.speaker: JOSEPHINE
turns.text: Five minutes.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Goodbye.

turns.speaker: JOSEPHINE
turns.text: Separate bedrooms?

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: JOSEPHINE
turns.text: But you will not... be safe...

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Not be safe?  What on earth are you talking about?

turns.speaker: JOSEPHINE
turns.text: In case of a... surprise attack... at night... I am such a... light sleeper... I could wake you... I could scream.

turns.speaker: JOSEPHINE
turns.text: Who is it?

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: It's me.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: I didn't mean the things that I said... I was angry and I said more than I meant to.

turns.speaker: JOSEPHINE
turns.text: Oh, my darling.  I'm sorry, too.  I won't do that again -- whatever you do.  I won't cause you any more embarrassment, I promise.

turns.speaker: JOSEPHINE
turns.text: Oh -- I didn't tell you... I've seen Dr. Corvisart, and he was very reassuring and encouraging.  He has had excellent results with the waters of Plombiers, and he thinks it would be a good idea for me to spend a few weeks there. Apparently, he sent Madame Le Floch there last year, and she gave birth to twins.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Indeed -- well, you may tell Dr. Corvisart, I should be entirely satisfied with half her success.

turns.speaker: JUNOT
turns.text: No, one cannot simply ignore it.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: I am afraid, then, I have to ask you both, Joseph as my brother, and Junot as my good friend, whether or not you know anything about this, or whether you saw anything at all during the trip which might make you suspect some truth to it.

turns.speaker: JUNOT
turns.text: I believe you sent for me.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Yes, yes, please sit down.  I will be with you in a moment.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: God damn it, Junot, wouldn't you think I have enough things on my mind not to waste time on a letter like this to Joseph?

turns.speaker: JUNOT
turns.text: There's probably some explanation.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Yes, I'm sure he's been too busy chasing his whores to be bothered about my wife.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Well, anyway, sorry to call you away from the festivities, but where is the breakdown on serviceable vehicles?  I asked for it yesterday.

turns.speaker: JUNOT
turns.text: I gave it to Berthier... this afternoon.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Why did you give it to him?

turns.speaker: JUNOT
turns.text: I thought he would be seeing you before I would, and would give it to you.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Well, he didn't give it to me, and when I ask you to do something for me, return the work to me, not to Berthier.

turns.speaker: JUNOT
turns.text: I'm sorry, I thought he would give it to you.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: I must have the breakdown now. Where is Berthier?

turns.speaker: JUNOT
turns.text: He's downstairs -- somewhere.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: All right, thank you.  Please ask him to come here.

turns.speaker: JUNOT
turns.text: Yes... but, first, can I say something to you, as a friend?

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Certainly.

turns.speaker: JUNOT
turns.text: I know that I shouldn't butt into things... that are really no concern of mine... but you shouldn't write a letter like that to Joseph.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: JUNOT
turns.text: Well, maybe he's only looking out for your best interests.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: What are you talking about?

turns.speaker: JUNOT
turns.text: Nothing.  That's all I can say.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: That's all you can say?  What are you talking about?

turns.speaker: JUNOT
turns.text: That's all I can say.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Now, just a minute.  You have just very clearly implied that there is a reason why Joseph should not give my wife the money which I left for her. I can't possibly allow a remark like that to go without explanation.

turns.speaker: JUNOT
turns.text: Let's just say, he looks after your interests.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Look, Junot, you aren't going to leave this room until you explain yourself.

turns.speaker: JUNOT
turns.text: There are some things... better left unsaid.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: You mean about my wife?!  You mean there are some things better left unsaid about Josephine?!

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: What the hell is the matter with you?

turns.speaker: JUNOT
turns.text: I didn't want to hurt you... All I wanted to do was to keep from hurting you.  I swear I didn't want to hurt you.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Well, whatever the hell you wanted to do, you are going to tell me everything right now.  Do you understand?!

turns.speaker: JUNOT
turns.text: You know that... letter you showed me in Milan -- the one about Hippolyte Charles?

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: JUNOT
turns.text: I wrote it.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: JUNOT
turns.text: Yes, I wrote it.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: You wrote it.

turns.speaker: JUNOT
turns.text: I couldn't face telling you.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: You couldn't face telling me what?

turns.speaker: JUNOT
turns.text: About Hippolyte Charles.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: What was there to tell?

turns.speaker: JUNOT
turns.text: My God, what do you think?

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Do you know what you're saying?

turns.speaker: JUNOT
turns.text: God help me -- yes.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: How do you know?

turns.speaker: JUNOT
turns.text: I know.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: How do you know?

turns.speaker: JUNOT
turns.text: I was in her maid's room at an inn we stopped at for the night, outside of Dijon.  It was an adjoining room to Madame Bonaparte's.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: You could hear them?

turns.speaker: JUNOT
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: You mean you heard them making love?

turns.speaker: JUNOT
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: How did you know it was Captain Charles?

turns.speaker: JUNOT
turns.text: I questioned the maid, and she admitted Charles had been Madame Bonaparte's lover for several months.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Can you give me a drink, please?

turns.speaker: JUNOT
turns.text: Yes, of course.  What do you want?

turns.speaker: JUNOT
turns.text: I wanted to kill him but Joseph convinced me it would be a mistake. He said people would say you hadn't the courage to deal with it yourself.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: And was it so widely known that Joseph had reason for such concern?

turns.speaker: JUNOT
turns.text: I believe so.  I believe Madame Bonaparte was not discreet, in Paris.

turns.speaker: MAJOR FIDON
turns.text: Good day, monsieur.  Do you think it is possible for you to tell your driver to stop ringing that bell?

turns.speaker: RUSSIAN GENTLEMAN
turns.text: My regrets, my dear Major, but I believe you have been blocking the road.

turns.speaker: MAJOR FIDON
turns.text: Are you trying to provoke me, monsieur?

turns.speaker: RUSSIAN GENTLEMAN
turns.text: No, Major, I merely wish to state that your vehicle appears to be somewhat slower and heavier than mine, and point out that, if you would be kind enough to pull over to one side of the road, I could pass you and be on my way.

turns.speaker: MAJOR FIDON
turns.text: May I inform you, monsieur, that I am Major Fidon, official courier to the court of the Emperor Napoleon, on my way to our Embassy at St. Petersburg and, in accordance with the rules of the road, no one may overtake or pass me.

turns.speaker: RUSSIAN GENTLEMAN
turns.text: Before you quote the rules of the road to me, Major, may I point out to you that you are not in France now, but that you are a guest in Russia.

turns.speaker: MAJOR FIDON
turns.text: If I have given you any cause to be insulted, monsieur, may I offer you immediate satisfaction?

turns.speaker: RUSSIAN GENTLEMAN
turns.text: If you wish to put things on that basis, then I will say good day to you, monsieur.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Good evening, ladies.  You must forgive me, my dearest wife, but I simply could not wait to see you.

turns.speaker: MARIE-LOUISE
turns.text: Oh, then you are...

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Yes, my dearest Marie-Louise, I am your husband.

turns.speaker: MARIE-LOUISE
turns.text: And, where did you see my portrait?

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Ah, you must forgive me, my dearest Marie-Louise, I saw it during one of my stays at your palace -- at Schonbrunn.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: And, you, my dear wife, do you find that I resemble my portraits?

turns.speaker: MARIE-LOUISE
turns.text: You are much younger, and much more handsome, than your pictures.

turns.speaker: MARIE-LOUISE
turns.text: Do you like music?

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Yes, I do -- very much.

turns.speaker: MARIE-LOUISE
turns.text: Will I be able to play the harp?  It is an instrument of which I am very fond.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Of course, my dear.

turns.speaker: MARIE-LOUISE
turns.text: You are so good to me.  Will you also allow me to have a botanical garden?

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: You may have anything you wish, my sweet and lovely Marie-Louise.

turns.speaker: MARIE-LOUISE
turns.text: I am told that Fontainebleau has many lovely views.  I know nothing more interesting than a lovely countryside.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: I am sure you will enjoy the French countryside.

turns.speaker: MARIE-LOUISE
turns.text: I hope you have patience with me.  I do not know how to dance the quadrille but, if you desire it, I will learn.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: I only desire what gives you pleasure, my dearest.

turns.speaker: MARIE-LOUISE
turns.text: Will it be possible to have my dog, Bijou, sent here?  I was not allowed to bring her and I love her so much.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Of course, my dear -- how cruel to have been separated from her.  And how strange it must be for you to be here, away from your family and everything you know.

turns.speaker: MARIE-LOUISE
turns.text: Oh, no, I am very happy.  But you must have patience with me... I know nothing at all of what a wife must know.  And I know nothing about men. My papa has never allowed me even to have a pet of the male gender.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Did the Emperor or Empress give you any... instructions of any kind... before you left?

turns.speaker: MARIE-LOUISE
turns.text: Papa said only to comply with any request you might make of me.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Oh, my dearest child -- you must not worry about anything.  I will teach you everything that you must know.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Do you know the joke about the two Swiss boys who go to a bordello for the first time?

turns.speaker: MARIE-LOUISE
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Well, two nice little Swiss boys, who are virgins, decide they will save up their money and go to a bordello.

turns.speaker: TALLEYRAND
turns.text: Article 46, calls for the virtual dismemberment of Prussia, reducing her population by half and her army to a token force.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Does she deserve anything better?

turns.speaker: TALLEYRAND
turns.text: Those are extremely harsh terms.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: I did not ask her to go to war against me.

turns.speaker: TALLEYRAND
turns.text: Has Alexander agreed to this?

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Yes, he has.

turns.speaker: TALLEYRAND
turns.text: Now, the section headed "Secret Clauses of the Treaty" -- Article 14b, provides for Alexander to serve as mediator between France and England and, if he fails to achieve a preliminary agreement within four months, it further provides that Russia is to go to war against England, and close her ports to English trade.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: That is correct.

turns.speaker: TALLEYRAND
turns.text: Do you think Alexander has any chance to succeed as a mediator?

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: I very seriously doubt it.  I don't think there is any possibility of making peace with England so long as she sees herself safe from invasion. That is why we must increase the pressure on her economy.  With Russia in the Continental Blockade, England must collapse.  More than 40% of her trade is with the Continent and Russia.

turns.speaker: TALLEYRAND
turns.text: England can make no move against you on the Continent without Austria.  A reliable treaty with Austria would end her hopes in that regard.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: We have a treaty with Austria.

turns.speaker: TALLEYRAND
turns.text: Not one I should like to rely on. Francis is still smarting under the terms he had to accept after Austerlitz, and he is under great pressure to recover his losses.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: My dear Talleyrand, none of the Kings of Europe bear any friendship for France.  It is easy for you to talk of reliable treaties.  The only treaties you have been able to negotiate are the ones I have won on the battlefield.

turns.speaker: TALLEYRAND
turns.text: What I am talking about is moderation.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: What you are talking about is a gamble on moderation -- when I gamble, I prefer to gamble on force.

turns.speaker: TALLEYRAND
turns.text: And where do you place Alexander?

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Alexander and I are friends.  We have reached an understanding.

turns.speaker: TALLEYRAND
turns.text: I hope that understanding is worth as much as you think it is, sire. My impression of Alexander is that he is moody and impressionable, capable of acting on sudden impulses which then lead to sudden embarrassments.  He is an unpredictable mixture of idealism and vanity.  You have dazzled him, and you have performed a diplomatic miracle, but Alexander is weak and he is easily influenced by the last one who has his ear.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: That is a matter of opinion.

turns.speaker: TALLEYRAND
turns.text: Sire, you have only enemies in the court of St. Petersburg, and I fear outside your influence, Alexander will have another look at what he has agreed to.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: He will stand by his agreement -- I know him better than you do.

turns.speaker: VARLAC
turns.text: Good day to our brothers-in-arms. Have you come to join us?

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: I am looking for Monsieur George Varlac who resides in the Rue de Frelicot.  Do you know him, monsieur?

turns.speaker: VARLAC
turns.text: Very well, Citizen Lieutenant.  You have come to the right place, for I am Citizen Varlac.

turns.speaker: VARLAC
turns.text: A revolution is not a polite discussion in a parlor, Citizen Lieutenant.  One does not call it murder to kill such vermin.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: You may save your philosophy for the magistrate, Monsieur Varlac.  I am only a simple officer in the army, and to me what you have done is called murder, and his always been called murder by honest men.

turns.speaker: VARLAC
turns.text: Then do you propose to arrest all of us, Citizen Lieutenant?  For I was not there alone.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: No, Monsieur Varlac, my warrant is only for you.  Now, will you please come down at once.  You will be taken back to Chalon for trial.

turns.speaker: VARLAC
turns.text: Citizen Lieutenant, my advice is to leave this town at once with your men.  We do not wish to do harm to our brothers in uniform.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Monsieur Varlac, do not pretend to speak for these good people whom you have misled and inflamed with violent speech.  Now, I order you to come down from the cart.

turns.speaker: VARLAC
turns.text: I suggest that you leave with your men while you can.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Monsieur Varlac, I will count slowly to five, and if you have not begun to get down from the cart by then, I will carry out your execution, on the spot.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: What did you say his name was?

turns.speaker: ORDERLY
turns.text: Eugene de Beauharnais.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Is he alone?

turns.speaker: ORDERLY
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Show him in.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Come in.

turns.speaker: ORDERLY
turns.text: Major Lavallette to see you, General.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Send him in.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Come in.

turns.speaker: ORDERLY
turns.text: A message from Citizen Fouche.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Let me have it.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Come in.

turns.speaker: ORDERLY
turns.text: Citizen Bourrienne to see you, sir.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Send him in.

turns.speaker: NARRATOR
turns.text: Napoleon was born at Ajaccio in Corsica on August 15th, 1769.  He had not been a healthy baby and his mother, Letizia, lavished him with care and devotion.  In middle age, he would write about her from St. Helena.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: My mother has always loved me.  She would do anything for me.

turns.speaker: NARRATOR
turns.text: His moods at this time were complex and varied.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Life is a burden for me.  Nothing gives me any pleasure; I find only sadness in everything around me.  It is very difficult because the ways of those with whom I live, and probably always shall live, are as different from mine as moonlight is from sunlight.

turns.speaker: NARRATOR
turns.text: He made friends with a family called Columbier, and would later write of his first flirtation with their daughter, Caroline.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: It will scarcely be considered credible, perhaps, but our whole business consisted in eating cherries together.

turns.speaker: NARRATOR
turns.text: Napoleon would soon arouse the resentment of the Directory in Paris, exceeding his authority, making political decisions and treaties like a Roman Conqueror, enlarging his role to ruler of Italy.  Only his tremendous success and ever increasing popularity prevented the Directory from replacing him.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: From that moment on, I foresaw what I might be.  Already I felt the earth flee beneath me, as if I were being carried away up to the sky.

turns.speaker: NARRATOR
turns.text: On December 2, 1804, Napoleon was made Emperor of France.  He would later say:  "I found the crown lying in the gutter and I picked it up."

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: Duroc, I have a bill here for 600,000 francs from Tirot, for building the Imperial throne and six decorated arm-chairs.  The amount is absurd -- and, at least twice too much.

turns.speaker: NARRATOR
turns.text: Led by the warlike Queen Louisa, and her fashion-minded husband, King Frederich Wilhelm, the Prussians still believed themselves cast in the mold of Frederick the Great, and more than a match for Napoleon.  The King had a special collection of 60 splendid uniforms, and was personally involved in the design of all the Prussian army uniforms.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: If the French army had been commanded at Jena and Auerstadt by a tailor, the King of Prussia would certainly have gained the day.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: I know Alexander.  His imagination must be struck by some great, bold, powerful stroke, and he will come back to me, just as he did at Friedland.

turns.speaker: NARRATOR
turns.text: With his army of 400,000 men in concealed bivouacs, on a ten mile front, in the forests, bordering the banks of the Vistula river, Napoleon conducted a last minute personal reconnaissance, disguised in the uniform of a Polish lancer.

turns.speaker: NARRATOR
turns.text: On January 1st, 1814, France itself was invaded.  Now, with a small army of raw recruits, Napoleon would have to face the powerful combination of England, Russia, Prussia and Austria, operating against him together, for the first time.  The balance of numbers had tilted irretrievably against him.

turns.speaker: NAPOLEON
turns.text: A year ago, the whole of Europe was marching alongside of us.  Today, the whole of Europe is marching against us.

turns.speaker: BABY'D
turns.text: Okay, I know what I want this time.

turns.speaker: DAY-DAY
turns.text: Anything you need.

turns.speaker: BABY'D
turns.text: Yo' cousin, Craig.  Hook us up.

turns.speaker: DAY-DAY
turns.text: That's it?

turns.speaker: BABY'D
turns.text: Just tell him to come over here and talk to me.

turns.speaker: DAY-DAY
turns.text: And I can go free?

turns.speaker: BABY'D
turns.text: Go, fo' I change my mind.

turns.speaker: UNCLE ELROY
turns.text: Hey, Debo, heard you running from a ass- whippin'?

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: Naw, it ain't like that.

turns.speaker: UNCLE ELROY
turns.text: If you see that boy again, bite off his ear off like Mike Tyson.

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: Alright, I'll remember that.

turns.speaker: UNCLE ELROY
turns.text: You know me?  I would've shot his big ass.  Hey, Willie, how's it going?  Still steppin' in dog shit every day?

turns.speaker: UNCLE ELROY
turns.text: Send Betty my love.  Boy you looking good.  I'mma take these in the house for you, man... and when you finish with this cat, come inside.  I got something to show you.

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: Thanks, Unc.

turns.speaker: UNCLE ELROY
turns.text: Man, that girl's gonna kill me one day. Viagra ain't working.  My back keep going out... she don't never get enough.  But check this out.  I got to lay some ground rules.  Your my family and I love you.  You're welcome to anything you want in my home. But I don't wanna catch you in the refrigerator or in my Suga bowl... you feel me knocking?

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: UNCLE ELROY
turns.text: Well, let me in.

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: Uncle Elroy, who's that girl by Day-Day's car?

turns.speaker: UNCLE ELROY
turns.text: Yeah, you gotta have a little money to live out here, Craig.  I never thought I'd be the kinda nigga to move to the suburbs.  But as soon as I got my check, I was gone.  Paid 230 thousand dollars cash on this house.

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: You paid cash?

turns.speaker: UNCLE ELROY
turns.text: Cash money.  They wasn't gonna stick me with no 30-year payment plan.  That's for suckas.  They got my daddy like that for a Cadillac years ago.  I got the only house on the block that's paid for. That's why I'm the king around here.

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: It's cool, but where's the water?

turns.speaker: UNCLE ELROY
turns.text: Don't need water.  We didn't have no pool in the projects...so none of us swim.

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: Y'all never use it?

turns.speaker: UNCLE ELROY
turns.text: Never...  But me and Suga can get real nasty in that Jacuzzi, though.

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: That's okay, Unc.  I can't swim, either.

turns.speaker: UNCLE ELROY
turns.text: Good.

turns.speaker: UNCLE ELROY
turns.text: I know you smoke weed, right?

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: Why you say that?

turns.speaker: UNCLE ELROY
turns.text: 'Cause your lips is getting black.

turns.speaker: UNCLE ELROY
turns.text: Negro, what the hell you doing to my woman?

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: I don't know!

turns.speaker: UNCLE ELROY
turns.text: Suga!

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: I don't know, I think I passed out or something.  I don't remember.

turns.speaker: UNCLE ELROY
turns.text: Passed out?  Can't hang, huh?  Boy, I knew you was a lightweight.  Passed out on one funky ass blunt.  They don't make 'em like they used to, baby.

turns.speaker: UNCLE ELROY
turns.text: No.  Thought he was with you.

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: Daddy, Uncle Elroy, I need your help.

turns.speaker: UNCLE ELROY
turns.text: Me, too.  You think they're in there?

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: Yup.

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: That's a nice piece of heat right there.

turns.speaker: UNCLE ELROY
turns.text: Thank you.  I only got two bullets in the mothafucka, but it's better than nothing.

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: Stretch it out.

turns.speaker: UNCLE ELROY
turns.text: Don't move me.

turns.speaker: D'WANA
turns.text: Who are you?

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: I'm his cousin.

turns.speaker: D'WANA
turns.text: We didn't come here for Day-Day.

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: Yes you did.

turns.speaker: D'WANA
turns.text: No we didn't.  We came to buy a CD.

turns.speaker: D'WANA
turns.text: Where's that boy that told me Day-Day was here?

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: I don't know... I think he went out the back.

turns.speaker: D'WANA
turns.text: Can I look for myself?

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: Where you going?

turns.speaker: D'WANA
turns.text: Ain't the rest room this way?  I gotta pee.

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: No I'm not.

turns.speaker: ROACH
turns.text: I'll do it.

turns.speaker: ROACH
turns.text: Great moves, Day-Day.

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: What happen?

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: What you mean talk to her?

turns.speaker: ROACH
turns.text: You know what he mean, dude.

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: I'm gone.

turns.speaker: ROACH
turns.text: For sure.  That's how I like 'em.

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: Not me.

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: Yeah it is...the best day before the weekend.

turns.speaker: ROACH
turns.text: That's fuckin' poetic, Craig.

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: What's the green stuff poking out?

turns.speaker: ROACH
turns.text: That's cron-don, sir.  My mom hates for me to smoke, so she made me bud-brownies. Wanna bite?

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: Naw, I already ate.

turns.speaker: ROACH
turns.text: Come on, Day, try it.  For moms.

turns.speaker: ROACH
turns.text: Sorry, bro, reflexes.  How did you do that?

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: Black magic.

turns.speaker: ROACH
turns.text: Me neither.

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: It's something in that hydraulic pump.

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: It's about to work, just come on.

turns.speaker: ROACH
turns.text: What about the dog?

turns.speaker: ROACH
turns.text: Dude, dogs hate me.  I don't know why. Me and K-9's just don't get along.

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: Well get along with this one.  Go ahead of us.  Don't get seen and don't let that mutt out of your sight.

turns.speaker: ROACH
turns.text: Fuck, what's his name?

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: Cheeco.

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: I ain't trying to rob you...

turns.speaker: PINKY
turns.text: Shut up!  Fo' I pump this Glock in yo' ass!  What did you do wit Day-Day and Roach?

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: Man, Day-Day is my people!

turns.speaker: PINKY
turns.text: I said shut up!  Now who sent you?

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: Nobody!

turns.speaker: PINKY
turns.text: If you say another word, it's over.  I'm not playing!

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: Shut up.  I been trying to tell yo' ass that... Day-Day is my cousin.  They're right there in the back.

turns.speaker: PINKY
turns.text: Whatever you say, man.  I didn't see shit.  The safe combination is 34-5-27. Just take it all.

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: What's crackin'?

turns.speaker: DAY-DAY
turns.text: You.  Hi, Uncle Willie.

turns.speaker: DAY-DAY
turns.text: You know it's been over a year since we kicked it last?  Up at the family reunion.

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: I know, that's when Uncle Elroy cussed out everybody, and threw up in Aunt Faye's backseat.

turns.speaker: DAY-DAY
turns.text: Yep.  I forgot about him cussin' out everybody.  Damn that was fun.

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: I know, we had a good time.  But ever since you guys moved out here, it seems like we've lost touch.

turns.speaker: DAY-DAY
turns.text: I know; this a long way from Watts.  But what I like about living out here is that you don't hear no helicopters, no sirens, no drive-by's, no nothing.  Just peace and quiet.  Listen.

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: Who is that?

turns.speaker: DAY-DAY
turns.text: Joker, he just got out of the pen.  Li'l Joker, he just got out of Youth Authority.  And Baby Joker, he just got out of Juvenile Hall.

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: They ever let you hit the switches on that Cadillac?

turns.speaker: DAY-DAY
turns.text: Naw, them dudes is assholes.  Especially that dog - Cheeco.  Watch this little ass, he's sneaky.  Plus, I got something better than a Cadillac.

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: This you?

turns.speaker: DAY-DAY
turns.text: Yeah, that's me.  Just a little somethin' somethin' I picked up.

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: Must be nice.  I wish we won the lottery. Come up on a million dollars like ya'll.

turns.speaker: DAY-DAY
turns.text: Man, after taxes, lawyer fees, and paying off my daddy's bad credit, we didn't end up with a million.  We bought this house and I spent the rest on this.  It's the bomb, huh?

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: This my baby.  I feel like a new nigga in this car.  I get mo' phone numbers rollin' this, than I ever did on the bus.

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: Man, this a cool house.

turns.speaker: DAY-DAY
turns.text: Thanks, I just wish my mother had a chance to see it.

turns.speaker: DAY-DAY
turns.text: Go on and make yourself at home.  I'mma go get dressed for work.

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: Oh, yeah, where you work at?

turns.speaker: DAY-DAY
turns.text: Pinky's Records and Disc in the shopping center.  I'mma talk to my boss and see if he got a little position for you.  'Cause you been unemployed for a long time now, Craig.

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: Thanks for reminding me.

turns.speaker: DAY-DAY
turns.text: I can't see!  I can't see!  Daddy!

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: Lay down, Day-Day.  Stop moving.

turns.speaker: DAY-DAY
turns.text: She pepper-sprayed me, man!  She pepper- sprayed me!

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: I know, be still.

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: You straight?

turns.speaker: DAY-DAY
turns.text: Yeah, I'm alright.  Is my face still orange to you?

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: Just a little.

turns.speaker: DAY-DAY
turns.text: I can't taste nothing.

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: What's the matter with your girlfriend?

turns.speaker: DAY-DAY
turns.text: Man, it's a long story.  I met D'Wana three months ago.  She had a little pudge in her stomach but I didn't pay it no attention.  Come to find out, she six months pregnant.  Saying I'm the daddy!

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: DAY-DAY
turns.text: Yeah, I broke up with her two Fridays ago and she's been harassing me ever since. She don't care about the restraining order or nothing.

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: Restraining order?  Where the hell you meet this girl?

turns.speaker: DAY-DAY
turns.text: I went back to Watts to sell my old car and met her on the way.  Worst day of my life.

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: Damn, you got a stalker.

turns.speaker: DAY-DAY
turns.text: That ain't the worst part.  Her little sister, Baby D.  She's the one that gets real physical.  But I got a restraining order on her, too.

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: You got a restraining order on a little girl named Baby D?

turns.speaker: DAY-DAY
turns.text: You don't know Baby D.

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: Who is that?

turns.speaker: DAY-DAY
turns.text: That's the sister.

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: Yo know what?  I'm starting to like Rancho Cucamonga.

turns.speaker: DAY-DAY
turns.text: I know what 'cha thinking.  I thought the same thing.  But it can't happen.

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: DAY-DAY
turns.text: Because, it's been a little tension between us ever since they got out the joint and ran their momma crazy.  And I'm just trying to keep the peace.  We moved out here to get away from that shit.

turns.speaker: DAY-DAY
turns.text: So.

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: What you mean, so?

turns.speaker: DAY-DAY
turns.text: If you 'get into it' with them S.A.'s and start a feud, you can always go back to home.  I gotta live here.  Just remember that.

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: I walked.

turns.speaker: DAY-DAY
turns.text: You walked?

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: Yeah, ya'll got a notice today.  It came certified mail.

turns.speaker: DAY-DAY
turns.text: You know what this is?

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: Yeah, that's why I walked down here.

turns.speaker: DAY-DAY
turns.text: How can they do this?

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: I don't know.  Did ya'll forget to pay it or something?

turns.speaker: DAY-DAY
turns.text: It says we owe $3,900...by tomorrow.

turns.speaker: CRAIG
turns.text: Damn...how much money ya'll got left from the lottery?
